values.title: Offset in bullet trimesh vertices

content.raw:
If you insert a model with a trimesh collision shape (such as the cordless drill or dumpster) into an empty world with bullet running, the object comes to rest with a gap between it and the ground. There is probably an offset problem somewhere.

We should make a test with some simple trimesh shapes (tetrahedron, cube) to ensure proper functionality.
content.html:
If you insert a model with a trimesh collision shape (such as the cordless drill or dumpster) into an empty world with bullet running, the object comes to rest with a gap between it and the ground. There is probably an offset problem somewhere.

We should make a test with some simple trimesh shapes (tetrahedron, cube) to ensure proper functionality.

values.title: Some bullet link params, such as gravity, are not set on init

content.raw:
A simple test is to add a camera sensor to the world and it falls through the ground, which it shouldn't because the gravity of its link is set to false.

reason for this is that `this->rigidLink` variable is always null when trying to set bullet link properties
content.html:
A simple test is to add a camera sensor to the world and it falls through the ground, which it shouldn't because the gravity of its link is set to false.

reason for this is that this->rigidLink variable is always null when trying to set bullet link properties

values.title: Incorrect ray sensor range values

content.raw:
Ray sensor is reporting distance to object measured from min range and not sensor origin.

Also need to fix the case when object is within min range.

Another related issue #124
content.html:
Ray sensor is reporting distance to object measured from min range and not sensor origin.

Also need to fix the case when object is within min range.

Another related issue #124

values.title: Lasert Test condition is too strict?

content.raw:
Testing machine is failing in the laser test (/test/regression/laser.cc:99) with the following error:

```
#!

Expected: (diffSum) < (1e-5), actual: 4.42444e-05 vs 1e-05
```

Is it safe to relax the condition or something is not working as expected?

values.title: Add set of physics test cases that run unthrottled

content.raw: Enable running of the physics integration tests unthrottled in addition to throttled. See the code in c8c6ba2 and add a parameter to the test functions, similar to the _physicsEngine parameter.
content.html: Enable running of the physics integration tests unthrottled in addition to throttled. See the code in c8c6ba2 and add a parameter to the test functions, similar to the _physicsEngine parameter.

values.title: Building Editor menu glitch

content.raw: When I'm trying to work in Gazebo, the building editor seems to create its own menu bar overriding the menu bar for Gazebo, even once I close the BE.  So on the top bar in Linux, I no longer see the Gazebo menu, regardless of whether the window is maximized or not.  No matter how many times I say "exit building editor", that menu seems to stay stuck on the top.  Am I doing something wrong?
content.html: When I'm trying to work in Gazebo, the building editor seems to create its own menu bar overriding the menu bar for Gazebo, even once I close the BE. So on the top bar in Linux, I no longer see the Gazebo menu, regardless of whether the window is maximized or not. No matter how many times I say "exit building editor", that menu seems to stay stuck on the top. Am I doing something wrong?

values.title: issues with reset buttons

content.raw:
- pressing the "Reset Model Poses" button doesnt set velocites to zero - so if robot is moving (e.g. falling over) when this is pressed then it will continue with these velocites.
This makes the button not very useful - please add velocity reset

- pressing the "Reset World" button resets the entire world - including SIM TIME! This smashes ROS interaction as the ROS core assumes incrementally increasing time.
Please do not reset the sim time
content.html:
• pressing the "Reset Model Poses" button doesnt set velocites to zero - so if robot is moving (e.g. falling over) when this is pressed then it will continue with these velocites. This makes the button not very useful - please add velocity reset

  • pressing the "Reset World" button resets the entire world - including SIM TIME! This smashes ROS interaction as the ROS core assumes incrementally increasing time. Please do not reset the sim time

values.title: better sensor rate control (moving average)

content.raw: per [issue](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/123/slower-camera-framerate-in-drcsim-20), a better frame rate throttling is suggested (i.e. moving average) for sensor updates.
content.html: per issue, a better frame rate throttling is suggested (i.e. moving average) for sensor updates.

values.title: Vertical sensor doesn't works

content.raw:
In the model.sdf, if I change a sensor from horizontal to vertical doesn't works properly. Also I had changed some parameters..and nothing. I think that's a bug from Gazebo, because Gazebo also loads the model with vertical a bit slower than the original with horizontal sensor.

PS: It's from 1.3.1 version, I can't update the version because I'm working in my thesis with this version, if in 1.4 it's solved, please, notify me and erase this issue. Thanks.

EDIT: It's a ray sensor, with libRayPlugin.so (so I think that this doesn't matter..)

In the model.sdf, if I change a sensor from horizontal to vertical doesn't works properly. Also I had changed some parameters..and nothing. I think that's a bug from Gazebo, because Gazebo also loads the model with vertical a bit slower than the original with horizontal sensor.

values.title: Lots of phantom joints in gazebo GUI when trying to move a model fixed to the world frame

content.raw:
If you try to move a model that has a fixed link to the world frame, it will cause numerous joint coordinate frames to be drawn. 

See the video for more detail:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UqsWUL_UAEQ&feature=youtu.be

If you try to move a model that has a fixed link to the world frame, it will cause numerous joint coordinate frames to be drawn.

values.title: ODE trimesh drop test fails

content.raw: Dropping a cube_20k in ode mode results in the mesh bouncing to the side on impact with the ground which should not happen.

values.title: Missing support for concave mesh in bullet

content.raw: Right now all meshes are loaded as btConvexTriangleMeshShape in bullet. We need to support concave shapes so that, for example, a robot would be able to grasp a cordless drill.
content.html: Right now all meshes are loaded as btConvexTriangleMeshShape in bullet. We need to support concave shapes so that, for example, a robot would be able to grasp a cordless drill.

values.title: Include Google Protobuf .proto files for Simulator in the binary builds

content.raw: Including .proto files in the installation package would allow Developers using non-supported Gazebo language platforms that are supported by Google protobuf  language bindings to be compiled for sending messages to the Gazebo Simulator.
content.html: Including .proto files in the installation package would allow Developers using non-supported Gazebo language platforms that are supported by Google protobuf language bindings to be compiled for sending messages to the Gazebo Simulator.

values.title: Missing documentation on contact data returned by ContactSensor

content.raw: Per [this thread](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/1448/i-dont-understand-the-contact-sensor-data/?comment=1463#comment-1463), we need to add documentation to [ContactSensor.hh](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/6895056f713b95e21418640132aabbae37fac7ff/gazebo/sensors/ContactSensor.hh?at=default#cl-91), describing in detail each element, contact point frame of reference, etc.

values.title: Check if file is a valid SDF before trying to parse it as SDF.

content.raw:
From [discussion on warning messages](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/315/fix-multiple-non-default-group-collision/diff#comment-125403).

In place of calling `readDoc` from [gazebo/sdf/interface/parser.cc:277](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/08aa8f0efd3d59927ace425345972fedd761423e/gazebo/sdf/interface/parser.cc?at=sandia_hand_multi_collision_fix#cl-277) and [gazebo/sdf/interface/parser.cc:305](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/08aa8f0efd3d59927ace425345972fedd761423e/gazebo/sdf/interface/parser.cc?at=sandia_hand_multi_collision_fix#cl-305), do a check to see if the incoming model is SDF first, then perform `readDoc` or conversion from URDF accordingly.  This way, we can avoid unnecessary warnings from failures to parse valid URDF files as SDF.
content.html:
From discussion on warning messages.

In place of calling readDoc from gazebo/sdf/interface/parser.cc:277 and gazebo/sdf/interface/parser.cc:305, do a check to see if the incoming model is SDF first, then perform readDoc or conversion from URDF accordingly. This way, we can avoid unnecessary warnings from failures to parse valid URDF files as SDF.

values.title: IMU sensor init() method

content.html:
bug in the IMU sensor

the override of Sensor::Init() method in IMU is

void ImuSensor::Init()
{
}

while in other sensors is (e.g., in ContactSensor)

void ContactSensor::Init()
{
  Sensor::Init();
}

in this way, the IMU sensor does not load properly the update_rate value and other stuff

values.title: Option to Disable ODE Joint Feedback (Patch included)

content.raw:
I've added in an option to disable joint feedback (but still use contact detection) in the world SDF (v1.3) and the ODEPhysics class, and have attached a Git-formatted patch.

Can some form of this be included in the core version?
Or is there an easier way to make this happen?

P. S. It might have been more appropriate to put this option in another section other than "solver", such as "constraints."
content.html:
I've added in an option to disable joint feedback (but still use contact detection) in the world SDF (v1.3) and the ODEPhysics class, and have attached a Git-formatted patch.

Can some form of this be included in the core version? Or is there an easier way to make this happen?

P. S. It might have been more appropriate to put this option in another section other than "solver", such as "constraints."

values.title: heightmap causes gazebo segfaults

content.raw:
using the drc terrain height map, I have been driving the drc vehicle (the polaris) around.

Behaviour is much better than when i last used heightmaps (about Dec 2012) but after a variable amount of time (about 2-3 mins), gazebo crashes without warning.

I think this is a major bug. I'm using gazebo 1.4 and drcsim 2.0

content.html:
The simple arm and simple gripper models seem to be working, but the Simple Arm Gripper model is not working in either ODE or Bullet. Inserting the model causes some links to not appear or to fly around everywhere. It may be a plugin issue.

Also, I observered a gzserver crash one time while running under ODE, with the failure coming at ODEPhysics.cc:867:

content.raw:

See [bullet issue 687](http://code.google.com/p/bullet/issues/detail?id=687#c2).

See bullet issue 687.

values.title: Assert in pull request #310 kills drcsim after 15 seconds

content.raw:
Gazebo pull request #310 introduces some GZ_ASSERT's into the sensor manager. I approved it, but I should have tested it with drcsim, because gazebo is exiting after about 15 seconds of sim time when running `roslaunch atlas_utils atlas_drc_vehicle_firehose.launch`. We should probably change that to a gzerr or gzwarn for the time being.
~~~
***** Internal Program Error - assertion (eventTime >= common::Time::Zero) failed in void 
gazebo::sensors::SensorManager::SensorContainer::RunLoop():
/home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo2/gazebo/sensors/SensorManager.cc(467): 
Time to next sensor update is negative.
~~~

values.title: Potentially infinite loop in ServerFixture::SpawnSDF causing test failure

content.raw:
The PhysicsTest.CollisionFilteringODE has failed several times in Jenkins with a Timeout after 240 seconds. I've traced the problem to a potentially infinite loop in [ServerFixture::SpawnSDF at line 784](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0e2cbdaf75faaae74ed3163dc39bdd5c98ec6796/test/ServerFixture.hh?at=default#cl-783).

http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64/232/testReport/junit/(root)/Results/test_ran/

http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64/56/testReport/junit/(root)/Results/test_ran_2/

The test failure is intermittent. I see it consistently when compiled RelWithDebugInfo and when run without gdb on an ssh terminal without an X display. I found the place where it got stuck with some printf's.

values.title: Use multiple texture maps per dae mesh

content.raw:
Currently, only one texture map is handled per collada file. However, a mesh can have a diffuse, specular, ambient, emission, etc textures. Take a look at the lamp_post model in the model database.

Example Normal Ambient Occlusion Specular Map shader:
[http://www.ogre3d.org/tikiwiki/Normal+AO+Specular+Mapping+Shader](http://www.ogre3d.org/tikiwiki/Normal+AO+Specular+Mapping+Shader)

values.title: Numerous potential infinite loops in ServerFixture

content.raw:
Many of the Spawn functions (SpawnBox, SpawnSphere, etc) in ServerFixture have potentially infinite loops that wait for the model to be spawned:
~~~
while (_wait && !this->HasEntity(_name))
  common::Time::MSleep(10);
~~~

These should be given a timeout.

List of functions:

[GetPercentRealtime](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/3b71414a1c761150cc84fda2f2cd9220f9296f64/test/ServerFixture.hh?at=default#cl-236), 
[SpawnCylinder](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/3b71414a1c761150cc84fda2f2cd9220f9296f64/test/ServerFixture.hh?at=default#cl-575), 
[SpawnSphere](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/3b71414a1c761150cc84fda2f2cd9220f9296f64/test/ServerFixture.hh?at=default#cl-615), 
[SpawnSphere (different arguments)](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/3b71414a1c761150cc84fda2f2cd9220f9296f64/test/ServerFixture.hh?at=default#cl-658),
[SpawnBox](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/3b71414a1c761150cc84fda2f2cd9220f9296f64/test/ServerFixture.hh?at=default#cl-697),
[SpawnTrimesh](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/3b71414a1c761150cc84fda2f2cd9220f9296f64/test/ServerFixture.hh?at=default#cl-740),
[SpawnEmptyLink](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/3b71414a1c761150cc84fda2f2cd9220f9296f64/test/ServerFixture.hh?at=default#cl-769).
content.html:
Many of the Spawn functions (SpawnBox, SpawnSphere, etc) in ServerFixture have potentially infinite loops that wait for the model to be spawned:

while (_wait && !this->HasEntity(_name))
  common::Time::MSleep(10);

These should be given a timeout.

List of functions:

GetPercentRealtime, SpawnCylinder, SpawnSphere, SpawnSphere (different arguments), SpawnBox, SpawnTrimesh, SpawnEmptyLink.

content.raw:
I just started using ``gazebo_1.5`` which includes the updated ``SensorManager`` from pull request #332 and it crashes immediately when gravity gets enabled for Atlas:

This happens by simply running ``roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch`` and unpausing simulation - it crashes right when the simulator hits second 10, i.e. when gravity gets enabled.

values.title: gzsdf ignores or parses incorrect some URDF parameters

content.raw:
gzsdf in version 1.3 does not translate all parameters inside URDF correctly and ignores some completely.

In my URDF description I define a ray sensor like this:

```
#!xml

  <gazebo reference="cliff_sensor_left_link">
    <sensor:ray name="cliff_sensor_left">
      <alwaysActive>true</alwaysActive>
      <rayCount>50</rayCount>
      <rangeCount>1</rangeCount>
      <resRange>1.0</resRange>
      <minAngle>-0.04361</minAngle>
      <maxAngle>0.04361</maxAngle>
      <minRange>0.01</minRange>
      <maxRange>0.15</maxRange>
      <displayRays>true</displayRays>
    </sensor:ray>
  </gazebo>
```

This gets transformed into the below:

```
#!xml

      <sensor name='cliff_sensor_left' type='ray'>
        <ray>
          <scan>
            <horizontal>
              <samples>1</samples>
              <resolution>0.000000</resolution>
              <min_angle>-0.000761</min_angle>
              <max_angle>0.000761</max_angle>
            </horizontal>
            <vertical>
              <samples>1</samples>
              <min_angle>0.000000</min_angle>
              <max_angle>0.000000</max_angle>
            </vertical>
          </scan>
          <range>
            <min>0.010000</min>
            <max>0.150000</max>
            <resolution>1.000000</resolution>
          </range>
        </ray>
        <pose>0.087340 0.136010 0.031600 3.141593 1.570793 3.141593</pose>
      </sensor>
```

A bunch of things go wrong here:

* `<alwaysActive>` and  `<displayRays>` are ignored.
* There is a degree to radians conversion happening in the angle parsing.
* `<rayCount>` does not translate to <samples> or <resolution>
* `<resRange>` does not translate to <samples> or <resolution>


Looks to me like, the parser doesn't get enough love lately. :-)
content.html:
gzsdf in version 1.3 does not translate all parameters inside URDF correctly and ignores some completely.

In my URDF description I define a ray sensor like this:

  <gazebo reference="cliff_sensor_left_link">
    <sensor:ray name="cliff_sensor_left">
      <alwaysActive>true</alwaysActive>
      <rayCount>50</rayCount>
      <rangeCount>1</rangeCount>
      <resRange>1.0</resRange>
      <minAngle>-0.04361</minAngle>
      <maxAngle>0.04361</maxAngle>
      <minRange>0.01</minRange>
      <maxRange>0.15</maxRange>
      <displayRays>true</displayRays>
    </sensor:ray>
  </gazebo>

This gets transformed into the below:

      <sensor name='cliff_sensor_left' type='ray'>
        <ray>
          <scan>
            <horizontal>
              <samples>1</samples>
              <resolution>0.000000</resolution>
              <min_angle>-0.000761</min_angle>
              <max_angle>0.000761</max_angle>
            </horizontal>
            <vertical>
              <samples>1</samples>
              <min_angle>0.000000</min_angle>
              <max_angle>0.000000</max_angle>
            </vertical>
          </scan>
          <range>
            <min>0.010000</min>
            <max>0.150000</max>
            <resolution>1.000000</resolution>
          </range>
        </ray>
        <pose>0.087340 0.136010 0.031600 3.141593 1.570793 3.141593</pose>
      </sensor>

A bunch of things go wrong here:

  • <alwaysActive> and <displayRays> are ignored.
  • There is a degree to radians conversion happening in the angle parsing.
  • <rayCount> does not translate to <samples> or <resolution>
  • <resRange> does not translate to <samples> or <resolution>

Looks to me like, the parser doesn't get enough love lately. :-)

values.title: rotations in ray sensor pose turns into weird translations and behaviour

content.raw:
I have placed my ray sensor links using RViz. However, I couldn't find them when in visualised in Gazebo. So, I started playing around with their pose in the SDF description.

It turned out that translations alone work well. However, once rotations are applied, things get confusing.

A rotation around x results in a translation in the z-plane [1]. A rotation around y cuts a bit off the rays [1], [2] and a rotation around z results in a translation in the y-plane [1].

Here two pictures:

[1] 
![ray sensor rotation bug](https://googledrive.com/host/0ByNsBDTjiuOycWJOSFgwX0VFM00)

[2]
![ray sensor rotation bug - cut rays](https://googledrive.com/host/0ByNsBDTjiuOydk1VWHFwOVktVHc)
content.html:
I have placed my ray sensor links using RViz. However, I couldn't find them when in visualised in Gazebo. So, I started playing around with their pose in the SDF description.

It turned out that translations alone work well. However, once rotations are applied, things get confusing.

A rotation around x results in a translation in the z-plane [1]. A rotation around y cuts a bit off the rays [1], [2] and a rotation around z results in a translation in the y-plane [1].

Here two pictures:

[1]

[2]

values.title: Problems removing sensors with new SensorManager

content.raw:
If you delete a model containing a ray sensor or IMU (try the hokuyo model for example) and there are no other sensors of that type in the world, then the console spams an error message:
~~~
Error [SensorManager.cc:498] Updating a sensor containing without any sensors.
Error [SensorManager.cc:498] Updating a sensor containing without any sensors.
Error [SensorManager.cc:498] Updating a sensor containing without any sensors.
Error [SensorManager.cc:498] Updating a sensor containing without any sensors.
~~~

Inserting and deleting the camera model doesn't lead to this error message.

UPDATE: I can't reproduce the following crash.

values.title: Request: Change contact reference frame from global to local for msgs::Contact

content.raw:
Just realised that the reference frame for a contact point is the global frame. I would have expected the position being given in reference to the collision object frame.

In my use case I need to define different behaviour depending on where the contact point is on the collision model (Kobuki has 3 bumper sensors).

Is just me being confused by the current definition?
Or are there other reasons to do it the way it's currently done?

Is just me being confused by the current definition? Or are there other reasons to do it the way it's currently done?

values.title: undefine `RANDOMLY_REORDER_CONSTRAINTS` in ODE

content.raw:
do not use [RANDOMLY_REORDER_CONSTRAINTS](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a3b9596dc9e6ee289fe03c603102a4561ac1dc4f/deps/opende/src/quickstep.cpp?at=default#cl-92).

It has undefined consequences to frictional contacts, potentially violating ordering of normal->friction solutions.
content.html:
do not use RANDOMLY_REORDER_CONSTRAINTS.

It has undefined consequences to frictional contacts, potentially violating ordering of normal->friction solutions.

values.title: SensorManager assert during jenkins test failure

content.raw:
The Sensor_TEST unit test failed on a [recent jenkins build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo_1.5/job/gazebo-gazebo_1.5-devel-precise-amd64/9/testReport/junit/%28root%29/Results/test_ran/). The failure was caused by a GZ_ASSERT failure in SensorManager.cc

~~~
61: [1;36mDbg[0m sent reset world message
61: ***** Internal Program Error - assertion (diffTime >= common::Time::Zero) failed in void gazebo::sensors::SensorManager::SensorContainer::RunLoop():
61: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-gazebo_1.5-devel-precise-amd64/gazebo/gazebo/sensors/SensorManager.cc(479): Took negative time to update a sensor.
~~~

This is a race condition, but I've been able to make it more prevalent by stress testing Reset World with an unthrottled ray sensor. The was added in changeset c3ebcf3 to branch [sensor_reset_stress](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/sensor_reset_stress..gazebo_1.5).
content.html:
The Sensor_TEST unit test failed on a recent jenkins build. The failure was caused by a GZ_ASSERT failure in SensorManager.cc

61: [1;36mDbg[0m sent reset world message
61: ***** Internal Program Error - assertion (diffTime >= common::Time::Zero) failed in void gazebo::sensors::SensorManager::SensorContainer::RunLoop():
61: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-gazebo_1.5-devel-precise-amd64/gazebo/gazebo/sensors/SensorManager.cc(479): Took negative time to update a sensor.

This is a race condition, but I've been able to make it more prevalent by stress testing Reset World with an unthrottled ray sensor. The was added in changeset c3ebcf3 to branch sensor_reset_stress.

values.title: Joint::GetAngle and corresponding GetAngleImpl ignores parameters

content.raw: In the [Joint::GetAngle(int)](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a3b9596dc9e6/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc?at=default#cl-398) implementation, corresponding `GetAngleImpl(int)` calls in ode ignores joint index parameters (e.g. see [ODESliderJoint::GetAngleImpl(int)](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a3b9596dc9e6ee289fe03c603102a4561ac1dc4f/gazebo/physics/ode/ODESliderJoint.cc?at=default#cl-62).
content.html: In the Joint::GetAngle(int) implementation, corresponding GetAngleImpl(int) calls in ode ignores joint index parameters (e.g. see ODESliderJoint::GetAngleImpl(int).

values.title: Joint::GetAngle returns Angle, which is confusing for non-angular joints

content.raw:
Typical usage right now expects user to do:

~~~
   double sliderPosition = myJoint->GetAngle().Radian()
~~~

even for prismatic joints, or joints with non-angular positions.  This is potentially confusing.
content.html:
Typical usage right now expects user to do:

   double sliderPosition = myJoint->GetAngle().Radian()

even for prismatic joints, or joints with non-angular positions. This is potentially confusing.

values.title: Thread in sensor manager can potentially sleep forever

content.html:
in SensorManager::SensorContainer::RunLoop()

When calculating sleep time:

  // Calculate an appropriate sleep time.
  if (maxUpdateRate > 0)
    sleepTime.Set(1.0 / (maxUpdateRate));
  else
    sleepTime.Set(0, 1e6);

if no update rate is specified then maxUpdateRate evaluates to GZ_DBL_MIN which results in 1.0/GZ_DBL_MIN sleep time

values.title: Setting the rate of real-time simulator

content.raw:
Can a module be added to set the rate of simulation e.g. with the gui

I've created my own plugin to do this and its very simple - just sleeping occasionally but it does the job.

This is a basic feature. Maybe it already exists?

values.title: cmd_vel Atlas gliding slows down Gazebo over time

content.raw:
When controlling Atlas via the cmd_vel topic Gazebo slows down dramatically over time. When I try to move Atlas along the road in vrc task 1 I start with a real-time factor of 0.5 in the pen, by the time I reach the first corner it's down to ~0.22 and by the time I reach the second corner it's just 0.15 ... this does not seem to have a lower limit, I usually give up once it reaches 0.08 (or earlier).

This is not related to the world the robot is in as I'm also able to reproduce this by moving in a circle in an empty world. In an empty world however the real-time factor goes up to ~2.0 when I start moving the robot and within 20 second slows back down to ~1.0 and by the time sim-time hits 60 seconds I'm down to a real-time factor of ~0.23 ... stopping movement only causes very little recovery (e.g. it goes from ~0.23 to ~0.3 when I stop moving at ~0.23).

I was worried that this might also occur when the robot moves itself and I had it walk for ~50 meters or so but I did not see a change in performance so it only seems to be related to the teleportation movements that cmd_vel is using.

While this doesn't seem like too big of a deal it is fairly annoying for e.g. testing perception as it consumes more and more time the more you try to move the robot.
content.html:
When controlling Atlas via the cmd_vel topic Gazebo slows down dramatically over time. When I try to move Atlas along the road in vrc task 1 I start with a real-time factor of 0.5 in the pen, by the time I reach the first corner it's down to ~0.22 and by the time I reach the second corner it's just 0.15 ... this does not seem to have a lower limit, I usually give up once it reaches 0.08 (or earlier).

This is not related to the world the robot is in as I'm also able to reproduce this by moving in a circle in an empty world. In an empty world however the real-time factor goes up to ~2.0 when I start moving the robot and within 20 second slows back down to ~1.0 and by the time sim-time hits 60 seconds I'm down to a real-time factor of ~0.23 ... stopping movement only causes very little recovery (e.g. it goes from ~0.23 to ~0.3 when I stop moving at ~0.23).

I was worried that this might also occur when the robot moves itself and I had it walk for ~50 meters or so but I did not see a change in performance so it only seems to be related to the teleportation movements that cmd_vel is using.

While this doesn't seem like too big of a deal it is fairly annoying for e.g. testing perception as it consumes more and more time the more you try to move the robot.

values.title: gazebosim.org/wiki has weird issue with external links

content.raw:
I added some descriptions of physics parameters to one of the tutorials:
http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/1.5/make_world/modify

I was trying to include links to the ODE manual entries on CFM and ERP like these:

http://ode-wiki.org/wiki/index.php?title=Manual:_Concepts&oldid=316#Constraint_Force_Mixing_.28CFM.29

I was unable to get it to work using the media wiki syntax

~~~
[http://ode-wiki.org/wiki/index.php?title=Manual:_Concepts&oldid=316#Constraint_Force_Mixing_.28CFM.29 Constraint Force Mixing]
~~~

It would only parse up to the first underscore as url and interpret the rest as the label. I ended up using tinyurl to make parseable links, but I wanted to document the problem in case anyone else runs into it.

http://gazebosim.org/wiki/BrokenLinkDemo

values.title: VRC heightmap problems

content.raw:
Given that the other heightmap related ticket was "resolved" and the pull-request merged I'll open a ticket to re-iterate the current heightmap problems:

## Texture distortion (or some underlying problem that causes this): 

The texture moves with the camera which makes it look like it's ~20cm farther away than it actually is. A video demonstrating the effect of texture moving around, notice how it moves across the edges of triangles (this is using the heightmap with just one texture and no normal map): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eC_1MiATQBE

A picture of the stereo point cloud of the ground in front of the robot at the same height of the robot which appears ~20cm below the actual height (red grid is at -0.2m, gray grid at 0m): http://i.imgur.com/d5IxVbb.png


## Extremely poor LIDAR performance: 

When turning on the LIDAR in vrc world 2 (walking), the real-time factor drops down from ~0.99 to 0.02 (no hands, no rubble). In vrc world 1 it is not as bad, there it only drops about 0.1 (e.g. from 0.5 to 0.4) and in the old world that used ``drc_terrain`` I never noticed a difference when enabling the LIDAR as far as I can remember. 

The difference between those worlds is that both ``vrc1`` and ``vrc2`` use a heightmap with 513*513 resolution but vrc1 has a map size of 500x500x118 while ``vrc2`` only has a map size of 200x200x46.9. So ``vrc1`` is more than twice as large as ``vrc2`` and has a better performance for LIDAR. Assuming that Gazebo/OGRE creates one vertex per pixel, this means that  ``vrc2`` has a higher triangle density than ``vrc1`` which explains why it's slower than ``vrc1``. ``drc_terrain`` has a heightmap resolution of 257px and a map size of 2000x2000x500 which is ten times larger than ``vrc2`` and hence explains why those issues didn't arrise with ``drc_terrain``. 

I converted the vrc2 heightmap into a triangle mesh, one with 132098 triangles and the other with 526338 to test speed with pure triangle meshes - I'm not sure what triangle count vrc2 has but it should be close to one of them. With the lower resolution triangle mesh my real-time factor only dropped by 0.05 and with the higher resolution mesh it only dropped by 0.1. But again I'm not sure whether either of them is close to the resolution that the heightmap rendered by Gazebo/Ogre has.

Maybe this performance drop might decrease or even disappear when switching to the GPU based LIDAR given that enabling the cameras does not affect performance that much either?


## Errors/differences/bugs/.. in collision geometry: 

Visual geometry and collision geometry are different at some parts of the terrain, or maybe the collision geometry is buggy. See http://youtu.be/r6aH04E_F_8 and http://youtu.be/TXkw3nV1OR0 for some examples. This makes walking on the heightmap even more difficult and unpredictable than it already is with all the other heightmap related bugs and problems listed above.


## Atlas gliding, slipping, falling through heightmap:

Another day, another bug (or at least partially a variant of the one above): 
Atlas slips, glides, and/or falls through the heightmap when it gets close to an edge. Example of extreme slipping (or maybe small penetrations that make it slip forward): http://youtu.be/ojSBBKH9Ne8  and an example of atlas falling through the heightmap for several centimeters: http://youtu.be/5fKJtuXpIks
content.html:
Given that the other heightmap related ticket was "resolved" and the pull-request merged I'll open a ticket to re-iterate the current heightmap problems:

Texture distortion (or some underlying problem that causes this):

The texture moves with the camera which makes it look like it's ~20cm farther away than it actually is. A video demonstrating the effect of texture moving around, notice how it moves across the edges of triangles (this is using the heightmap with just one texture and no normal map): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eC_1MiATQBE

A picture of the stereo point cloud of the ground in front of the robot at the same height of the robot which appears ~20cm below the actual height (red grid is at -0.2m, gray grid at 0m): http://i.imgur.com/d5IxVbb.png

Extremely poor LIDAR performance:

When turning on the LIDAR in vrc world 2 (walking), the real-time factor drops down from ~0.99 to 0.02 (no hands, no rubble). In vrc world 1 it is not as bad, there it only drops about 0.1 (e.g. from 0.5 to 0.4) and in the old world that used drc_terrain I never noticed a difference when enabling the LIDAR as far as I can remember.

The difference between those worlds is that both vrc1 and vrc2 use a heightmap with 513*513 resolution but vrc1 has a map size of 500x500x118 while vrc2 only has a map size of 200x200x46.9. So vrc1 is more than twice as large as vrc2 and has a better performance for LIDAR. Assuming that Gazebo/OGRE creates one vertex per pixel, this means that vrc2 has a higher triangle density than vrc1 which explains why it's slower than vrc1. drc_terrain has a heightmap resolution of 257px and a map size of 2000x2000x500 which is ten times larger than vrc2 and hence explains why those issues didn't arrise with drc_terrain.

I converted the vrc2 heightmap into a triangle mesh, one with 132098 triangles and the other with 526338 to test speed with pure triangle meshes - I'm not sure what triangle count vrc2 has but it should be close to one of them. With the lower resolution triangle mesh my real-time factor only dropped by 0.05 and with the higher resolution mesh it only dropped by 0.1. But again I'm not sure whether either of them is close to the resolution that the heightmap rendered by Gazebo/Ogre has.

Maybe this performance drop might decrease or even disappear when switching to the GPU based LIDAR given that enabling the cameras does not affect performance that much either?

Errors/differences/bugs/.. in collision geometry:

Visual geometry and collision geometry are different at some parts of the terrain, or maybe the collision geometry is buggy. See http://youtu.be/r6aH04E_F_8 and http://youtu.be/TXkw3nV1OR0 for some examples. This makes walking on the heightmap even more difficult and unpredictable than it already is with all the other heightmap related bugs and problems listed above.

Atlas gliding, slipping, falling through heightmap:

Another day, another bug (or at least partially a variant of the one above): Atlas slips, glides, and/or falls through the heightmap when it gets close to an edge. Example of extreme slipping (or maybe small penetrations that make it slip forward): http://youtu.be/ojSBBKH9Ne8 and an example of atlas falling through the heightmap for several centimeters: http://youtu.be/5fKJtuXpIks

values.title: Standalone executable crashes when gazebo is not yet started

content.html:
If you try to ::init() before gazebo has started, it promptly dies. Here's a workaround but I'm not sure exactly how to 'fix' it...

hg diff
diff -r 9c55354cbb52 gazebo/transport/Connection.cc
--- a/gazebo/transport/Connection.cc    Sat Mar 09 15:02:07 2013 -0500
+++ b/gazebo/transport/Connection.cc    Sat Mar 09 20:48:47 2013 -0500
@@ -148,8 +148,8 @@
   if (!this->connectCondition.timed_wait(lock,
         boost::posix_time::milliseconds(60000)) || this->connectError)
   {
-    gzlog << "Failed to create connection to remote host["
-          << host << ":" << _port << "]\n";
+    //gzlog << "Failed to create connection to remote host["
+    //      << host << ":" << _port << "]\n";
     this->socket->close();
     return false;
   }

Basically, gzlog has not yet been initialized when the initial connection to Master is attempted, so it bombs.

values.title: View Joints Show Wrong Orientation

content.raw:
When selecting "View->Joints" in gazebo, the orientation shown for the joints are incorrect, and different from what is shown by RViz as a TF. 

RViz shows the correct orientation, while all the orientations of the robot seem to be matching the world's orientation, but then will move along with the robot. 

The errors can really be seen in the hands. I'm not sure if this is because their is something specifically wrong with the hands, or if all the others just happen to start at the same orientation as the world. (I am assuming the latter).

values.title: gazebo performance sensitive to existence of sensor rendering thread or gzclient

content.raw:
With a valid display,

~~~
roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch gzname:=gzserver
~~~

`gzstats` yields roughly 2.16X real-time factor:

~~~
Factor[2.16] SimTime[26.31] RealTime[11.85] Paused[F]
~~~

However, if I disable rendering by supplying a bogus `DISPLAY`:

~~~
export DISPLAY=:1282.3282
roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch gzname:=gzserver
~~~

`gzstats` shows 10~15% performance improvement:
~~~
Factor[2.41] SimTime[135.76] RealTime[56.67] Paused[F]
~~~

Not sure if it's related, but similar slow down appears if `gzclient` is started on a remote machine.
content.html:
With a valid display,

roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch gzname:=gzserver

gzstats yields roughly 2.16X real-time factor:

Factor[2.16] SimTime[26.31] RealTime[11.85] Paused[F]

However, if I disable rendering by supplying a bogus DISPLAY:

export DISPLAY=:1282.3282

gzstats shows 10~15% performance improvement:

Factor[2.41] SimTime[135.76] RealTime[56.67] Paused[F]

Not sure if it's related, but similar slow down appears if gzclient is started on a remote machine.

values.title: Occasional bandwidth test failures, timeout in ServerFixture

content.raw:
We're having several intermittent failures of the bandwidth test.

* [gazebo_1.5 #15 bandwidth](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-gazebo_1.5-devel-precise-amd64/15/console)
* [gazebo_1.5 #17 bandwidth](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-gazebo_1.5-devel-precise-amd64/17/console)
* [gazebo_default #242 bandwidth](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64/242/console)

The tests start but fail to load the server within the 30 second timeout specified in [ServerFixture:130-136](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2ed06f79d13f07666115e722cdfd8db82f099fd0/test/ServerFixture.hh#cl-130)
~~~
69: [==========] Running 1 test from 1 test case.

values.title: boost::shared_*_cast are deprecated, removed in boost 1.53

content.raw:
Gazebo has `boost::shared_static_cast()` and `boost::shared_dynamic_cast()` function calls in many places, but this function was deprecated as long ago as boost 1.35 (search for deprecated in http://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_35_0/boost/shared_ptr.hpp) and has been removed in boost 1.53 (latest version). The recommend instead to use `boost::dynamic_pointer_cast()`.

I came upon this while trying to compile on OS X and using the ros/groovy homebrew of ogre, which uses the latest boost version.
content.html:
Gazebo has boost::shared_static_cast() and boost::shared_dynamic_cast() function calls in many places, but this function was deprecated as long ago as boost 1.35 (search for deprecated in http://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_35_0/boost/shared_ptr.hpp) and has been removed in boost 1.53 (latest version). The recommend instead to use boost::dynamic_pointer_cast().

I came upon this while trying to compile on OS X and using the ros/groovy homebrew of ogre, which uses the latest boost version.

values.title: Incorrect ray sensor behavior when attached to fixed joint with rotation

content.raw:
This bug is related to and possibly a duplicate of issue #543 and issue #509.

Using a ray sensor attached to another link through a fixed joint produces weird behavior when the rotation of the fixed joint is non-zero.

This behavior includes seeing through walls in some places as well as the sensor data being rendered incorrectly when visualized in Gazebo.

When published to RVIZ, the sensor data is not weirdly translated.

I only saw the "through the wall" behavior using a world generated from the willow_walls_heightmap included in the simulator_gazebo package.
content.html:
This bug is related to and possibly a duplicate of issue #543 and issue #509.

Using a ray sensor attached to another link through a fixed joint produces weird behavior when the rotation of the fixed joint is non-zero.

This behavior includes seeing through walls in some places as well as the sensor data being rendered incorrectly when visualized in Gazebo.

When published to RVIZ, the sensor data is not weirdly translated.

I only saw the "through the wall" behavior using a world generated from the willow_walls_heightmap included in the simulator_gazebo package.

values.title: Multiple steps per click on GUI step tool

content.raw: Currently the step button next to the time panel only moves forward one time step. The underlying World::StepWorld(int _steps) supports multiple steps, but the world_control message and gui interface only allow a single step. It would be very useful to have a way to specify an integer number of steps for use by the step button.
content.html: Currently the step button next to the time panel only moves forward one time step. The underlying World::StepWorld(int _steps) supports multiple steps, but the world_control message and gui interface only allow a single step. It would be very useful to have a way to specify an integer number of steps for use by the step button.

values.title: Problems with <camera><pose> element

content.raw:
<camera><pose> elements are not always parsed correctly by CameraSensor and MultiCameraSensor. CameraSensor does not parse them at all, and the MultiCameraSensor has an error in the pose math when the <sensor><pose> element has a rotation.

I've added a test world in 8caf855 to branch issue_camera_pose. Each Camera image should have the ground at the bottom of the frame. Additionally, the MultiCameraSensor should have a lateral offset, but there is a vertical offset instead.
content.html:
<camera><pose> elements are not always parsed correctly by CameraSensor and MultiCameraSensor. CameraSensor does not parse them at all, and the MultiCameraSensor has an error in the pose math when the <sensor><pose> element has a rotation.

I've added a test world in 8caf855 to branch issue_camera_pose. Each Camera image should have the ground at the bottom of the frame. Additionally, the MultiCameraSensor should have a lateral offset, but there is a vertical offset instead.

values.title: Fix joint memory leaks for bullet

content.raw: Issue #564 was related to memory leaks caused by joint creation and destruction and is fixed for ODE by pull request #383. A similar fix should be implemented for bullet.
content.html: Issue #564 was related to memory leaks caused by joint creation and destruction and is fixed for ODE by pull request #383. A similar fix should be implemented for bullet.

values.title: [PATCH] Gazebo 1.5 - SensorContainer::RunLoop() - Default maxUpdateRate causes a large sleep time to be requested

content.raw:
I had an issue where my ContactSensor's were not returning any data, even though contact messages were being published through ~/physics/contacts (but not through the entities' topics). This behavior did not occur in Gazebo 1.4.
After putting in some breakpoints, I saw that ContactSensor::UpdateImpl() was not called, went through the call stack, and found that SensorContainer::RunLoop() (a new structure introduced in 1.5, it seems) was hanging at the condition variable's wait() after initialization.

Looked into it, and found that it hung due to the default sleep time = 1.0 / maxUpdateRate, with maxUpdateRate being GZ_DBL_MIN (~1e-308).
I've changed the time values in the patch included and the sensor container seems to run properly. I don't think these values make sense, but hopefully they help point out the issue.
content.html:
I had an issue where my ContactSensor's were not returning any data, even though contact messages were being published through ~/physics/contacts (but not through the entities' topics). This behavior did not occur in Gazebo 1.4. After putting in some breakpoints, I saw that ContactSensor::UpdateImpl() was not called, went through the call stack, and found that SensorContainer::RunLoop() (a new structure introduced in 1.5, it seems) was hanging at the condition variable's wait() after initialization.

Looked into it, and found that it hung due to the default sleep time = 1.0 / maxUpdateRate, with maxUpdateRate being GZ_DBL_MIN (~1e-308). I've changed the time values in the patch included and the sensor container seems to run properly. I don't think these values make sense, but hopefully they help point out the issue.

values.title: Node::ProcessIncoming deadlocks on gazebo startup

content.raw:
in latest gazebo 1.5, if one tries to start gazebo and spawn an object at the same time, potentially arrive at a 3 way deadlock.  See attached gdb output:

  - thread 3:  locked receiveMutex, loadModelMutex, waiting on nodeMutex
  - thread 10: locked nodeMutex, waiting on incomingMutex
  - thread 13: locked incomingMutex, waiting on receiveMutex

This is from spawning pr2 using pr2_empty_world.launch on gazebo 1.5 branch.
content.html:
in latest gazebo 1.5, if one tries to start gazebo and spawn an object at the same time, potentially arrive at a 3 way deadlock. See attached gdb output:

  • thread 3: locked receiveMutex, loadModelMutex, waiting on nodeMutex
  • thread 10: locked nodeMutex, waiting on incomingMutex
  • thread 13: locked incomingMutex, waiting on receiveMutex

This is from spawning pr2 using pr2_empty_world.launch on gazebo 1.5 branch.

values.title: <collision><max_contacts> element not currently used

content.raw:
The <collision><max_contacts> sdf parameter is documented as overriding the global <physics><max_contacts> parameter, but it is not currently used.

http://gazebosim.org/sdf/dev.html#max_contacts88

values.title: Atlas robot gets stuck sometimes around limits

content.raw:
We have noticed that sometimes the back roll (back_ubx) on Atlas can get stuck if it gets around the joint limits.  This seems to happen much more frequently when using an effort-only conotrller rather than a position PID controller.

We have found that we can apply max efforts (+ or - 95) and not get any velocity or position change when at the limit (around -0.8 or 0.8 radian for back_ubx).  

We have also found (oddly) that we can get unstuck by pushing into the "physical" limits of the joints, causing the sim to move beyond the limits of the joint (similarly, sometimes simply setting effort to 0 and letting gravity pull it past the limts works).  Once you are significantly away from the limit (in either the positive or negaive direction), efforts start to work again.  

I traced through Gazebo, and it seems this may go all the way through to the way ODE handles limits when sending torques.   This is pretty easy to replicate though.  Just set all effort on the back_ubx to 0, let it tip to the side, then try to lfit back up with lets say 70 effort (away from limt).  It won't make it, but it should put it right in the sweet spot to get stuck.  After that any effort away from the limit won't work.  Pressing hard into the limit, ususlaly breaks it out of this state and lets you move back away.
content.html:
We have noticed that sometimes the back roll (back_ubx) on Atlas can get stuck if it gets around the joint limits. This seems to happen much more frequently when using an effort-only conotrller rather than a position PID controller.

We have found that we can apply max efforts (+ or - 95) and not get any velocity or position change when at the limit (around -0.8 or 0.8 radian for back_ubx).

We have also found (oddly) that we can get unstuck by pushing into the "physical" limits of the joints, causing the sim to move beyond the limits of the joint (similarly, sometimes simply setting effort to 0 and letting gravity pull it past the limts works). Once you are significantly away from the limit (in either the positive or negaive direction), efforts start to work again.

I traced through Gazebo, and it seems this may go all the way through to the way ODE handles limits when sending torques. This is pretty easy to replicate though. Just set all effort on the back_ubx to 0, let it tip to the side, then try to lfit back up with lets say 70 effort (away from limt). It won't make it, but it should put it right in the sweet spot to get stuck. After that any effort away from the limit won't work. Pressing hard into the limit, ususlaly breaks it out of this state and lets you move back away.

values.title: Sensor reinsertion causes assertion

content.raw:
Using gazebo/default around fd5dc00db9df, if I insert a Hokuyo, then delete it, then insert another one, most of the time I get this assertion:

    ***** Internal Program Error - assertion (diffTime.sec < 1) failed in void gazebo::sensors::SensorManager::SensorContainer::RunLoop():
    /home/gerkey/code/drc/gazebo/gazebo/sensors/SensorManager.cc(477): Took over 1.0 seconds to update a sensor.

values.title: Unable to set gazebo_ros_imu rpyOffset, xyzOffset

content.raw:
I have been trying to get the libgazebo_ros_imu.so plugin to work in gazebo, and it seems to come up just fine, but now I would like to modify the rpyOffsets, because for whatever reason the imu orientation coming from rostopic echo shows that it is negative by some offset. Essentially I am trying to run it the same way it is in typically done in what I have seen in examples. 

But I get this error:

Error [parser_urdf.cc:72] xml key [xyzOffset][0] value [xyzOffset] is not a valid double from a 3-tuple

Error [parser_urdf.cc:72] xml key [rpyOffset][0] value [rpyOffset] is not a valid double from a 3-tuple


I cannot seem to figure out how to modify that parameter for the IMU plugin.
Attached is the set of sensors I am trying to use with gazebo.

values.title: Gazebo needs test with URDF model

content.raw: None of the gazebo regression test involve URDF models. This allowed the SDF 1.4 change to break URDF parsing without us noticing. We should add a test that involves loading an URDF model.
content.html: None of the gazebo regression test involve URDF models. This allowed the SDF 1.4 change to break URDF parsing without us noticing. We should add a test that involves loading an URDF model.

values.title: VisualPlugin parameters lost on spawning a model

content.raw:
Visual elements are not created directly from the SDF in code, but indirectly by publishing a visual message. The plugin message does not support parameters, so any parameters inside a VisualPlugin are lost during this transfer.

See this answers.gazebosim.org thread for more context: http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/1986/why-does-sdf-plugin-syntax-not-support-additional/

I might attempt a patch as this is blocking some multi-robot HRI experiments we are trying to run inside Gazebo. I've tested this in Gazebo 1.3, but it seems like the problem persists in trunk as well.
content.html:
Visual elements are not created directly from the SDF in code, but indirectly by publishing a visual message. The plugin message does not support parameters, so any parameters inside a VisualPlugin are lost during this transfer.

See this answers.gazebosim.org thread for more context: http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/1986/why-does-sdf-plugin-syntax-not-support-additional/

I might attempt a patch as this is blocking some multi-robot HRI experiments we are trying to run inside Gazebo. I've tested this in Gazebo 1.3, but it seems like the problem persists in trunk as well.

values.title: Sporadic spikes in imu data

content.raw:
Threading issue

Imu sensor from the sensor thread grabs sim time and velocity from the physics thread without locking which occasionally results in inconsistent sim time and velocity pairs that are off by one time step. This produces accelerations that are either 0 or twice the actual value.
content.html:
Threading issue

Imu sensor from the sensor thread grabs sim time and velocity from the physics thread without locking which occasionally results in inconsistent sim time and velocity pairs that are off by one time step. This produces accelerations that are either 0 or twice the actual value.
